column7: Joan of Navarre was imprisoned at Pevensey Castle after her confessor accused her of plotting to kill King Henry V with witchcraft. Her fortune was seized
column8: and she remained in captivity until her release in 1422.

column5: Elizabeth was in sanctuary at Westminster Abbey when accusations of witchcraft were being publicly used against her and her family.

column7: Eleanor Cobham was accused of treasonable necromancy after consulting astrologers who predicted King Henry VI’s illness
column8: leading to a highly publicized trial. Found guilty of witchcraft and conspiracy
column9: she was forced to perform public penance

column5: Evidence of Jacquetta's witchcraft was brought to Warwick Castle - it was a small metal man-of-arms
column6: broken in half and fastend with wire!

column2: -0.09358936692314447 The Stoning of Dr. Lamb https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Lambe Lambe’s reputation as a “devilish” sorcerer grew alongside ever-stranger stories of storms
column5: until frightened Londoners viewed him as both mountebank and menace. Their fear hardened into fury after the notorious assault on young Joan Seager
column6: and when court favour shielded him from the scaffold
column7: a mob outside the Fortune finally delivered its own sentence in stones. #approx
